fields.name: FLY TYING: BRIAN'S SIMPLE SCUD
fields.notes: Brian Chan ties a simple Scud (Freshwater Shrimp) pattern and talks about the best time to fish Scuds and why they are such an important food item for Trout and other fish species.
fields.author: Brian Chan

fields.name: FLY TYING: BRIAN'S DLT Micro Leech
fields.notes: Brian Chan ties up a very innovative Leech Pattern that imitates a variety of lake food sources, like leeches, damselfly nymphs, and even Freshwater Shrimp.
fields.author: Brian Chan

fields.name: Alfred's Boatman | Fish It on the Surface or Below
fields.notes: This buoyant pattern can be fished at the surface when fish are actively taking boatman at or just below the surface.  You can also use a clear intermediate, Type III, or faster sink rate line to drag the fly down.  Dragging the fly down simulates the u-shaped travel path the natural boatmen take back and forth to the surface to replenish their air supply.
fields.author: Phil Rowley

fields.name: FLY TYING: CHAN'S ASB WINE CHIRONOMID
fields.notes: Brian Chan ties his Anti-Static Bag Wine Chironomid and explains why wine/maroon colors are so important along with talking about how various materials mimic gases trapped by chironomids as they emerge.
fields.author: Phil Rowley

fields.name: Stimulator Fly Tying - Randall Kaufmann Fly Pattern
fields.notes: The Stimulator is an amazing fly pattern developed by fly tying legend Randall Kaufmann.  The Stimulator was originally developed to imitate a stonefly adult.  But that is not the only insect the Stimulator imitates.  The Stimulator also emulates a grasshopper, caddis or even large drake mayflies!  The Stimulator is also a great dry fly for fishing a dropper underneath.  The bushy profile and deer hair make the Stimulator a highly buoyant fly.  The Stimulator is most often tied in olive, orange, black and yellow.  Usually tied in sizes #06-16.

fields.name: How to Fish: Dragonfly Fly Fishing Strategies
fields.notes: Learn how to catch trout in this beginners’ guide to fishing. Dragonflies are a popular food source for trout and other fish in British Columbia’s lakes. Freshwater fishing expert Brian Chan covers the dragonfly life cycle and fishing strategies for targeting trout feeding on dragonflies.
fields.author: Brian Chan

fields.name: How to Fish: Leech Fly Fishing Strategies
fields.notes:
Learn how to catch trout in this beginners’ guide to fishing. For more information on freshwater fishing in British Columbia, Canada, visit https://www.gofishbc.com

B.C. fishing icon, Brian Chan, shares some of his extensive knowledge on British Columbia’s aquatic freshwater insects and worms. Discover some of Brian's top techniques for catching fish.

Leeches are a common food source for trout and other fish in British Columbia’s lakes. Learn more about leech fishing patterns, the optimal gear set-up, and retrieval techniques targeted at trout feeding on leeches.
fields.author: Brian Chan

fields.name: How to Fish: Scud or Shrimp Fly Fishing Strategies
fields.notes: Learn how to catch trout in this beginners’ guide to fishing. Shrimp and scuds are popular food sources for trout and other fish in British Columbia’s freshwater lakes. TV personality and fishing icon, Brian Chan, covers the lifecycle of the caddisfly and fishing strategies for targeting trout feeding on the shrimp and scuds.
fields.author: Brian Chan

fields.name: How to Fish: Damselfly Fly Fishing Strategies
fields.notes: Learn how to catch trout in this beginners' guide to fishing. The damselfly is a popular food source for trout and other fish in British Columbia’s lakes year-round. Freshwater fishing expert Brian Chan covers the life cycle of the damselfly and fishing strategies for targeting trout feeding on the damselfly hatch.
fields.author: Brian Chan

fields.name: How to Fish: Water Boatman and Backswimmer Fly Fishing Strategies
fields.notes: Learn how to catch trout in this beginners’ guide to fishing. Water boatman and backswimmers are popular year-round food sources for trout and other fish in British Columbia’s lakes. Freshwater fishing expert Brian Chan covers the life cycle of water boatman and backswimmers and fishing strategies for targeting trout feeding on them.
fields.author: Brian Chan

fields.name: How to Fish: Caddisfly Fly Fishing Strategies

Freshwater fishing expert Brian Chan covers the lifecycle of the caddisfly and fishing strategies for targeting trout feeding on the caddisfly hatch, which occurs each year in late June/ early July in B.C.

fields.name: How to Fish: Mayfly Fly Fishing Strategies
fields.notes: Learn how to catch trout in this beginner’s guide to fishing. The mayfly is a popular food source for trout and other fish in British Columbia’s lakes. In this video, freshwater fishing expert Brian Chan covers the life cycle of the mayfly and fishing strategies for targeting trout feeding on the mayfly hatch.

fields.name: Gold Ribbed Hares Ear
fields.notes: In today’s video, Rick (The FlyFish Fanatic)™ will be tying what is probably my favorite trout river pattern, PERIOD, The Hare’s Ear. This fly has always done well for me, I tie in many different sizes and with and without a bead head. This and the Pheasant tail are definitely my goto patterns for any river that holds trout.

fields.name: Elk Hair Caddis Fly Pattern
fields.notes:
No fly vest is complete without a caddisfly imitation, and this one is my favourite. Getting the elk-hair
wing stacked properly on this fly is the greatest challenge for the tier, but when done correctly, the Elk
Hair Caddis is an ideal imitation for a variety of caddisfly hatches. The hackle wrapped over the body
makes the fly super-buoyant, helping it sit upright on the water. It also lets you skitter the fly across the
surface.
My most memorable day with the Elk Hair Caddis was on B.C.’s Whitetail Lake. The action had been
decent throughout the day, but it absolutely died as evening approached, despite the fact the fish were
rising like crazy. As I lifted my rod tip to bring in my Elk Hair Caddis and try a new pattern, the fly
danced across the surface and a big rainbow slammed it, breaking the tippet. I quickly tied on another
Elk Hair, and instead of allowing it to sit motionless, I began to retrieve it. Instantly, I got another
strike. That time I landed a big rainbow. And so went the action for the next couple of hours. Since that
day, I’ve used this technique often, even on flowing water, skittering the fly across the surface on a
tight line at the end of the drift. Just hang on, because strikes are explosive.

fields.name: Ruby Eyed Leech
fields.notes: Designed by Brian Chan, the Ruby Eyed Leech is a deadly leech pattern.  No stillwater fly box would be complete without a few Ruby Eyed Leeches in a variety of colors.  This black and red version has performed particularly well.  Not surprisingly, this one of our top selling leech patterns on our Stillwater Fly Fishing Store (www.stillwaterflyfishingstore.com)

fields.name: EVERY FLY FISHER SHOULD HAVE | HOW TO TIE A MIDGE | PUPA EMERGER & FLY
fields.notes:
Big bad articulated streamers are a ton of fun when the browns are on the hunt.. Watching any size trout suck down your massive foam dry fly can be enough to drive a man insane.. A tiny rock dwelling worm is not glamourous.. and is certainly not flashy.. But every angler needs to have a Midge or two in your box!
These are my three favorite Midge patterns to represent the three major stages in this little bugs lifecycle. Tying the midge pupa, midge emerger, and midge fly are all fairly simple and extremely effective.  These are my go to patterns for winter time fishing or if I were to stumble upon a cheeky tailwater.
fields.snippet: Tying the midge lifecycle

fields.name: Lake Talk Live-Water Boatman and Backsimmers
fields.notes:
Fall is at our doorsteps.  This means water boatmen and backswimmers will soon be taking flight to mate and migrate.  When these air-breathing insects return to the water they drive trout crazy initiating a concentrated feeding frenzy.

Watch as Brian Chan and I  talk about water boatmen and backswimmers. Learn about these unique aquatic insects along with our favorite patterns, presentation techniques, and on-the-water strategies.  At the end of this talk, I tie a couple of our favorite patterns.
fields.author: Phil Rowley

fields.name: BCFlyguys Quick Tips E05 - Fall Leeching
fields.author: BCFlyguys

fields.name: Fly Tying Tutorial Video- The All CDC Damsel
How to Tie the Apps Worm-Attractor or Imitator?
fields.notes:
How to tie the Apps Worm. Originally designed as a bloodworm (Chironomid larva) pattern Peter Applebly's Apps Worm has fast become one of my favorite stillwater fly patterns.  

Fellow stillwater fanatic Rhys from Rhys's Fishes convinced me to give this fly a try a few years ago, and I have never looked back.  Check out the links below to Rhys's channel and his Apps Worms Tying videos.

You can fish this fly under an indicator, retrieve it slowly using cast and retrieve techniques or strip it fast to trigger a reaction.  A superb fly that belongs in every stillwater fly box.

Apps Worm
Hook: Daiichi 1530 #10-#14
Thread: Glo Brite Floss
Tail:  Sexi-Floss, Stretch Floss or Spanflex
Body: Glo Brite Floss
Legs: Sexi-Floss, Stretch Floss or Spanflex
Antenna: Sexi-Floss, Stretch Floss or Spanflex
fields.author: Phil Rowley

fields.name: Foam Minnow
fields.notes: The Foam Minnow works well when presented in the shallows.  Its buoyant inner core keeps the fly up near the surface keeping it relatively free of snags and debris and most importantly in the view of minnow focused trout.  This pattern was also my featured pattern in the Jan/Feb 2014 issue of BC Outdoors Sport Fishing Magazine.
fields.author: Phil Rowley

fields.name: Slush Jelly Blob | Trout Candy!
fields.notes:
Slush Jelly or Slush Blob
Hook:  Daiichi 1120 (#10-#12) (https://www.canadianllama.com/daiichi...)
Thread:  UTC 70, Color to Compliment Body (https://bit.ly/335bgDc)
Tail:  Krinkle Mirror Flash (https://bit.ly/3n2WVz4)
Body:  Slush Jelly, Color to Match Zoo Plankton (https://www.canadianllama.com/fritz/s...)
Bead:  Gold, Brass (https://www.canadianllama.com/brass-b...) or Tungsten (https://www.canadianllama.com/tungste...)

A favorite attractor fly of mine when trout are feeding on zooplankton.  You can suspend this pattern beneath a strike indicator when trout are suspended in deep water.  Or fish it aggressively using a brisk 4-6-inch strip pause retrieve using a sinking line.  This pattern can also be used to attract or draw fish into other, perhaps more natural, patterns when using multiple flies.

If you want to learn more about how to fly fish lakes please download and subscribe to mine and Brian Chan’s Stillwater Fly Fishing App by selecting the appropriate link below. Our app includes specific tips on how we fish attractors including indicator tactics.

One of the app benefits is the ability to take our helpful content with you wherever you go. Once downloaded to your smartphone, Wi-Fi is not needed to access the over 100 video tips, and growing, contained across five different chapters, Entomology, Leaders & Knots, Strategies and Tactics, Equipment, and Stillwater Flies.
fields.author: Phil Rowley
fields.snippet: A favorite attractor fly of mine when trout are feeding on zooplankton.

fields.snippet: Hard to improve on our time tested & proven Zucchini chironomid pupa fly pattern, but we did think it would be an interesting take to put a bit of a classic buzzer spin to it! Whip some up and see what you think ... :)

fields.name: The Black Olive Chironomid
fields.notes: If you take a close look at a lot of the “black” chironomids in your samples you’ll quickly notice they will often actually be a very dark olive colour. This pattern will work when fish are on those or just the usual olive colours you see. Twist it up and have em for the spring and up your cronie game!

fields.name: Lake Turnover 101 with Brian Chan
fields.notes:
Ever wonder what happens after a winter thaw to the plants, oxygen and of course the fish in the lake? Brian Chan discusses the biology of turnover on a lake. This is the "Learning with the Pros" tip from Roche Lake from our Season 2 Premiere episode of BC Outdoors Sport Fishing.

Happens in all small lakes.
Just after ice off, the surface O2 rich water is colder and the bottom O2 poor water is warmer.  The warmth is caused by decomposing veg.
Four to seven days after ice off and on a windy day, the layers reverse and then mix.  This spreads the O2 all throughout the water column.  This means that there is not much O2 for fish or bugs and the catch comes right off.  As well the water gets very murky.  
Once the turnover happens, the O2 comes up across the lake and the hatches start.  The lake will clear up as well.
fields.author: Brian Chan
fields.snippet: Brian Chan discusses the biology of turnover on a lake

fields.name: How To Fish Attractor Patterns in a Lake - RIO Products
fields.notes:
In this episode of RIO's "How To" series, RIO ambassador Phil Rowley talks about how to fish attractor patterns in a lake using sinking lines. Attractor patterns (called "lures" in Europe) are flies that irritate and annoy trout; triggering bites from non-feeding fish. There are plenty of times an angler will get to a stillwater and find fish are not visually, or obviously, feeding, and on days like this, knowing how to fish such attractor flies can turn a bad trip into a very successful day on the water.

Phil talks about why and when you would fish attractor patterns, which retrieves to work with, what gear to use and explains about key fishing tactics like “Fishing The Hang” and “The Washing Line” – two deadly lake fishing techniques. 

If you are fly fish lakes for trout and want to increase your catch rates when fish are not feeding this video is a perfect lesson for you.
fields.author: Phil Rowley
fields.snippet: knowing how to fish such attractor flies can turn a bad trip into a very successful day on the water.

This video includes: understanding why trout eat batifish, what streamers to choose and why, flylines choices and much more! Subscribe to get all our video uploads: https://goo.gl/F82SBx
To learn more about fly fishing, check out the Orvis Learning Centre here: https://howtoflyfish.orvis.com

fields.name: How to Fish: Chironomid Fly Fishing Strategies | GoFishBC
fields.notes:
Learn how to catch trout in this beginners’ guide to fishing. Chironomids (or lake flies) are a popular food source for trout and other fish in British Columbia’s lakes. Freshwater fishing expert Brian Chan covers the life cycle of the chironomid and fishing strategies for targeting trout feeding on the chironomid hatch.

For more information on freshwater fishing in British Columbia, Canada, visit https://www.gofishbc.com

Brian shows examples of chironomid fly patterns, the optimal gear set-up, and retrieval techniques. The angler's goal is to imitate the behaviour of the hatching chironomid so that trout will snap up the fly.

This video is part of the How to Fish video series by GoFishBC. Watch the series to learn more about fly fishing techniques, gear selection, and the best times of year to go fishing.

fields.name: KNOTS
fields.notes:
Improved Clinch
    use with drys
    Having the tag end held, keeps the knot from slipping.

Non-slip mono-loop or Perfection loop
    Non-Slip Loop Knot Tutorial - https://youtu.be/Us0wL8KS4ww
    Used when we want to hang vertically or be able to swim.
     Good to make a loop for the fly line
     A short film showing how to tie the perfect Non Slip Loop Knot - https://youtu.be/dmN8TZqvgWk
     BEST KNOT Non-Slip Mono Loop - https://youtu.be/v27hXOQCkrc


Double/Triple Sergeons 
    It is fast
    Thinner use triple and larger use double

Blood knot
    Blood Knot: Tutorial - https://youtu.be/IB3_rePvDMU
    can tie in the middle of a line.

Nail Knot
    Used to attach leader to fly line and fly line to backing.

    Dropper knots
      - How To Tie Droppers and Knots - RIO Products - https://youtu.be/oAbz4AFxHLI

fields.notes: Don, Dale and Brian Chan fly fish Stump Lake near Kamloops, BC. Its late Fall and the fish are looking for any food items they can eat before winter sets in, which makes for some excellent Blob and Leech fishing. Don ties his Purple Micro Jig Leech on the bench.

fields.snippet: Its late Fall and the fish are looking for any food items they can eat before winter sets in,

The Two Toner Chironomid fly pattern is a great stillwater fly pattern that incorporates the ability to imitate a lot of different colors of a chironomid. See how we handle the two tones.

fields.name: Dangling Technique for Fly Fishing
fields.notes: Michael Gould "Ug" of 2Salt Travel describes the dangling technique for fly fishing on lakes and reservoirs. An effective way to fly fish with stillwater nymphs and leeches when trout hold very deep. Visit 2SaltTravel.com to connect with fly fishing lodges and outfitters around the globe.
fields.snippet: An effective way to fly fish with stillwater nymphs and leeches when trout hold very deep.

fields.name: Pike on a Fly | North Saskatchewan River Fly Fishing

fields.snippet: Phil Rowley travels down the North Saskatchewan River fly fishing for big pike and walleye.

fields.name: How to fish for Tiger Trout
fields.notes:
Tigers were first stocked in Alberta 2015 into three lakes Chain Lakes was one along with Black Nugget and East Twin (Manning). Since then the list of Tiger Trout lakes has grown.
In 2020 AEP will be stocking 29 lakes with Tiger Trout. Some Tiger trout lakes Like Chain are now stocked alternate years so it would be safe to say that the list of lakes in Alberta is 30 that are stocked with Tiger Trout. In this video, Gary Hanke discusses his approach to fishing for these aggressive fish, and how he has come to appreciate multi-species lakes. I hope you will enjoy this offering.
fields.author: Let's Go Outdoors

fields.name: Lake Talk Live-Understanding the Fall Season with Phil & Brian
fields.notes:
As summer wanes, air temperatures are starting to cool signifying the beginning of the fall season.  In my neck of the wood’s leaves are already starting to turn.  

For many fly fishers, such as myself and Brian Chan, these changes signify the beginning of the fall season, one of our favourite times of the year to be on the water.  

Join us as we discuss how lakes transition from summer to fall, gear, food sources, flies, and how our presentation and tactics evolve from the beginning of fall through until ice up.
fields.author: Phil Rowley & Brian Chan
fields.snippet: these changes signify the beginning of the fall season, one of our favourite times of the year to be on the water.

fields.name: Catching LOADS Of trout in ALBERTA! | Mitchell pond Alberta
fields.notes:
in todays video I'm at a little pond in Red Deer Alberta catching TINY but MIGHTY stocker rainbow trout! 



Gear used: Spoons & worms
4 foot ultra light spinning rod with 6 lb mono
fields.snippet: I'm at a little pond in Red Deer Alberta catching TINY but MIGHTY stocker rainbow trout!

fields.name: Fall Finale-Phil Rowley Fly Fishing
fields.notes:
Join me on the water as I managed to sneak out one last time this past fall just before ice up on one of my favorite local trout lakes.  

The water was in the high 30's and the lake was just coming out of fall turnover.  We had to work throughout the day using boatman, Blobs and micro leeches but we managed to find a few fish.

Don't forget to check out mine and Brian Chan's Stillwater Fly Fishing App.  Our currently contains over 100 video tips including additional detail for some of the specific presentation techniques and tactics we used on this trip.   Once downloaded to your smartphone no Wi-Fi connection is needed to access the content.  It’s like having Brian and me on the water with you.

Check out the links below to what worked best, the equipment we used and to download and subscribe to the Stillwater Fly Fishing app.
fields.author: Phil Rowley
fields.snippet: We had to work throughout the day using boatman, Blobs and micro leeches but we managed to find a few fish.

fields.name: FLY FISHING: BABY DAMSELFLY NYMPHS
fields.notes: Don and Brian Chan fly fish Morgan Lake near Kamloops, BC. Its mid April and the guys expected to use leeches and blobs but it turns out the fish were keyed on Baby Damsels and Mayfly Nymphs. Brent Schlenker ties his Ultimate Damselfly Nymph on the bench.
fields.author: Brian Chan

fields.name: Figuring Out a Lake-Phil Rowley Fly Fishing Strategy
fields.notes:
Join me on the water as I get on the water early for one of my stillwater fly fishing schools at British Columbia's Corbett Lake Lodge.

Prior to the start of any on-the-water stillwater fly fishing school, I like to experiment with different techniques, tactics, and flies appropriate to the season so I can pass along what I learned to my students so they can catch fish too.
fields.author: Phil Rowley

The Washing Line, many of you will already know this super effective way to catch fish. In this video I am going to tie a few of my favourite patterns for the tactic. I will also be talking through and explaining how and why I set up for fishing. I have time indexed the video for ease of use. 

Please let me know what you think in the comments section below.

fields.name: Chironomids in Stillwaters, Kamloops Edition with Brian Chan
fields.notes: Brian Chan, fisheries biologist and Stillwater Master, fishes the trout and bug rich lakes of the Kamloops region of B.C, just a half day’s drive from Missoula. He has honed his techniques and flies over decades to come up with a system of fishing midges that we can use on our own fertile lakes such as Georgetown and Browns. His presentation will explain the midge life cycle and outline the key fly fishing strategies to become consistently successful when fishing this prolonged aquatic insect hatch. Pattern selection, key larval and pupal presentation techniques will be shared with you to use wherever you find midges. Brian’s presentation will feature various macro images and video clips of the real larvae and pupae along with representative fly patterns and the latest materials being used to imitate these life stages. Best of all, Brian will conclude with a discussion of the fabulous stillwater fisheries found in the greater Kamloops area.
fields.author: Brian Chan
fields.snippet: Mast class on Chironomids

fields.name: 5 Tips for Fly Fishing Big Lakes from Shore
fields.author: Jordan Oelrich
fields.snippet: Fly fishing big lakes can be a daunting tasks, especially without a boat! Today's episode discusses 5 tips for fly fishing from shore on big waterbodies!

fields.name: S3 E10 How To Fish Nymphs in a Lake Video
fields.notes: In this episode of RIO's "How To" series, RIO brand manager Simon Gawesworth explains and demonstrates how to fish nymphs in a lake or stillwater. Simon runs through some key retrieves that all nymph anglers need to use, and explains what the best rigs to fish nymphs and chironomids (buzzers) are.
fields.snippet: Every lake angler will find a time when fishing nymphs and chironomids is the very best way to catch fish, and this video is a perfect lesson for anyone wanting to increase their knowledge of this deadly style of fly fishing.

fields.name: Lake Talk-Let's Talk Electronics
fields.notes:
Be sure to watch this Lake Talk Live event, Let's Talk Electronics for the Fly Fisher.  

One of the most common subjects I receive questions about when it comes to fly fishing lakes surrounds electronics, what to buy, what features to consider, and how to use them. Join me and Andrew Humphrey as we talk about electronics for the stillwater fly fisher.  As the western Canada sales rep for Humminbird, Andrew is fluent in sounders and their use.  

Join us as we discuss sounders, their features, use and set up.
fields.author: Phil Rowley

fields.name: How to Fish: Setting Up Your Fly Rod | GoFishBC
fields.notes:
In this video for beginner anglers, Brian Chan discusses the various fishing rod types and how to set up a rod with fishing line and tackle. Learn how to catch trout and other freshwater fish!

For more information on freshwater fishing in British Columbia, Canada, visit https://www.gofishbc.com

Fishing rods come in different sizes and fishing line varies in weight and strength. In this video, Brian Chan explains the rod and line options available to consumers and the different situations each is designed for. For typical lake fishing in B.C., an 8 - 9ft rod and 5 or 6 weight line is ideal. 

Learn how to put line on a rod, what a leader is and how to set it to the optimal depth for the fish you are targeting. Discover some of the essential knots (clinch knot and non-slip loop knot) and how to attach a weight, swivel and strike indicator to your fishing line. 

Both floating and sinking line set-ups are covered in this video.
fields.author: Brian Chan
fields.snippet: Brian Chan discusses the various fishing rod types and how to set up a rod with fishing line and tackle.

fields.name: Adventure #26 2021 | Fishing with special guests! | Len Thompson Pond Alberta
fields.notes:
This Sunday I am fishing with friends of the channel Mike G. and Carson M.! They easily outfished me, Mike landed 4 trout using his fly rod and Carson landed a nice rainbow on his fly rod as well! Thanks for coming out guys! Looks like a flyrod might be in my future!

https://www.mydayoff.ca/

-Mike G. caught 4 Trout (2 on camera) he caught both Rainbow and Tiger on his fly rod @ 1:58 and 3:00 of the video, Thanks Mike, I hope you enjoy the video!

-Carson M. caught 1 nice Rainbow Trout on his flyrod as well! @ 8:22 of the video, Thank you Carson, I hope you had fun and enjoy the video!

-My Day Off skunked!  I'm kinda used to it lol.
fields.author: Matt (My Day Off)
fields.snippet: -Mike G. caught 4 Trout (2 on camera) he caught both Rainbow and Tiger on his fly rod @ 1:58 and 3:00 of the video, Thanks Mike, I hope you enjoy the video!

fields.name: World Champion Fly-Fisher "Jazz O'Driscoll" Shows us his Advanced Stillwater Leader Set-up
fields.notes:
Jazz O'Driscoll is a Stillwater Fly-fisherman from Alberta, CANADA. He has over sixty years of experience fly fishing around the world. He pioneered many tactical forms of fishing such as the Chironomid fishing under an indicator. Helped develop the "Slip Bodder Bobber" And is twice champion of the World Fly-Fishing Tournament

Jazz is known for mentoring people like Phil Rowley, Brian Chan, and inspiring many others to get into the sport of Stillwater Fly fishing. He generously takes some time while in front of the beautiful "Beaumont Pond" and teach's us some of the advanced leader set-up techniques he uses for fishing Chironomids under an indicator
fields.snippet: This is a joke video

fields.name: Chironomid Fly Fishing Basics
fields.notes:
Fly fishing chironomids on lakes can seem a little mysterious if you have never done it. This chironomid fly fishing video has broken down the basic tactics and ideas to help anyone just starting in lake fly fishing become a successful chironomid angler. 

In the first segment of this chironomid fishing tactics video I cover the gear and flies needed to begin chironomid fishing. The second section I cover what types of water to fish with chironomids. In the final segment I show you some basic techniques for determining the depth of the water and the retrieval rate when fishing chironomids. 

Thanks for watching and let me know if you have any questions!

Flies Used In This Video:

fields.name: How to Roll Cast — Fly Fishing For Beginners
fields.notes: In today's Beginner Fly Fishing Masterclass video, we'll be covering how to roll cast a fly rod in 4 easy steps! The roll cast is very useful when you have limited back cast room or if you are fishing with heavy nymph rigs. The roll cast is a must-have fly cast to add to your fly fishing arsenal. So grab your fly rod, reel, fly line, leader... and let's get casting!

fields.name: 5 Fundamentals of Fly Tying Hooks
fields.notes:
If you're an avid fly tier or just starting out, you've probably come across what seems like thousands of fly tying hooks and wondered what the differences are. In this video, we'll be exploring the different types of fly tying hooks and their unique characteristics.

We'll cover the classic dry fly hook, known for its lightweight design and ability to float on the water's surface. Then, we'll move on to the versatile nymph hook, which is great for imitating aquatic insects that live under the water’s surface. Next up, we have the streamer hook, perfect for tying larger patterns that imitate larger baitfish and crayfish.

But wait, there's more! We'll also delve into jig hooks, which are gaining popularity for their unique design that allows the fly to ride hook point up, reducing snagging on the bottom.

By the end, you'll have a better understanding of the different types of fly tying hooks and which ones are best for your specific needs.

fields.name: The ABCs of Fly Tying Thread
fields.notes:
In this video, we'll walk through the ABC's of fly tying thread. This comprehensive guide will cover everything from sizing systems, to structures, to material type, to colors, and how to use each! Our goal is to eliminate the confusion the next time you look at a spool of thread... polyester, nylon, denier, 6/0... No problem!

Throughout the video, we'll go over helpful visuals and diagrams to make it easy to follow along. We'll also share recommendations for some of the best fly tying thread brands on the market and answer common questions.

Whether you're a beginner or an experienced fly tier, this video is packed with valuable information and insights. So grab your tools and materials and join us for this deep dive into the world of fly tying thread!

fields.name: How to Successfully Fly Fish With Emergers
How to Setup for Pike Fly Fishing | Leaders, Flies, Flylines
fields.snippet: They're fly fishing for big pike and discuss the flies, fly lines and leaders needed for pike fishing.

fields.name: Fly Tying Tips: Articulating Streamers
fields.snippet: Wire vs Mono vs Braid......all things articulating streamers.

fields.name: How To Fly Fish An Intermediate Line In A Stillwater Lake
fields.notes:
In this episode of RIO's "How To Fly Fish" series, RIO brand manager Simon Gawesworth talks about fishing intermediate lines in a lake. The intermediate line should be the second line density every lake angler should buy (after a floating line), but few anglers know how to fish them, or the nuances behind using them.

Simon explains what an intermediate line is, talks about when to use a clear versus a "camo" intermediate line, as well as discussing the sink rate that makes the line an "intermediate". In this video, packed with tips for the lake angler, Simon also shows how to fish the "washing line" and the "hang", and runs through a couple of excellent tips that, if you are new to fishing intermediate lines, will really help your day.

Clearly explained in Simon's easy-going, simple-to-understand style, this is an excellent film for anyone who fly fishes in lakes - packed with great information and tips.
fields.author: Simon Gawesworth (Rio)
fields.snippet: Simon Gawesworth talks about fishing intermediate lines in a lake.

fields.name: The Catch Cast - Fly Fishing Tips and Tricks
fields.author: Simon Gawesworth (Rio)

fields.name: Easiest Way To Make A Loop Knot & Control The Size Of The Loop - Best Knot For Fishing
fields.notes: Making Loop Knots is not easy for everyone, and making the loop small and controlling its size is definitely not easy.  This video will walk you though the easiest way to make a small loop knot for any fly or lure.  We use a large hook and fly line in the second half of the video, which will hopefully help people easily follow the steps.
fields.snippet: fast way to tie a loop know to the fly.

fields.name: Fly clips
fields.notes: RIO's fly clips are ultra-fast, easy connection clips that allow anglers to change flies with extreme ease and speed, and prevents leaders and tippet sections getting too short. Simply tie the appropriate sized clip on to the end of your leader and either twist or clip on your fly. Multiple sizes of clip ensure that there is a clip size suitable for the majority of fly sizes.
fields.snippet: clips that allow anglers to change flies with extreme ease and speed

Be sure to listen to this week's episode. We cover:
- What to know about fishing egg patterns
- Is expensive fly line really worth it?
- How do I know if I'm fishing too deep?

fields.snippet: Pete Kutzer shows us how to improve our flyline casting and shooting the line farther.

fields.name: Chironomid Fly Fishing Brookies and Bows
fields.notes:
Fly fishing for Brook Trout and Rainbow Trout with Hand Tied Chironomid Flies in the Kamloops British Columbia area.  

LIVE CHIRONOMIDS!!!

I absolutely love these little critters. I love when people post throat samples, seeing them for myself. It is an excellent resource to see what the bugs actually look like if you are planning on purchasing chironomids or tying them yourself.

What exactly are you trying to emulate? Well this is exactly it.

Even though you may be like me before I used them, questioning how a fish could even find a chironomid in the water column being a size 16 or less... but let me tell you they do.

Seeing these chironomids will really help you understand how a simple single hook wrapped with some thread and wire can easily fool a fish. They look so similar.

Simple deadly patterns.

Seems the bulk hatches when I am fishing are either black, chrome or antistatic base with a chrome, black or copper looking rib. Some even look like a red rib.

There really are so many varieties, but these above color combos seem most prevalent.

Anyways I hope this video helps the aspiring fly tiers and chironomid anglers to give it a try.  I had more action, but the camera didn't want to run all the time I guess.

If you have any comments or questions leave them below.

Thanks for watching and SUBSCRIBE if you're new to the channel and HIT the NOTIFICATION BELL.

God Bless your adventure and good luck fishing.
fields.snippet: Fly fishing for Brook Trout and Rainbow Trout with Hand Tied Chironomid Flies

Every lake angler will find a time when fishing nymphs and chironomids is the very best way to catch fish, and this video is a perfect lesson for anyone wanting to increase their knowledge of this deadly style of fly fishing.

Pierre covers the best stillwater flies that all fly fishers need in their fly box, as well as how to fish each one and some info on how to tie them. Plus we have videos on how to tie many of these separately.

fields.name: Fly Fishing with a World Champion: Howard Croston on Small Stillwater Fishing
fields.notes:
In this video, Fulling Mill Signature Tyer Howard Croston walks us through his most used methods for small stillwater fly fishing. These are the three main tactics he employs if he doesn't know a small stillwater and wants to enjoy his day of fishing, or to get an idea of how it will fish. As he's often fishing completely new bodies of water in competitions, these are tactics that have proven themselves time and time again.

This video is broken into three parts: pulling lures, nymph fishing, and dry fly fishing. All three tactics have their time and place on small stillwaters, and Howard goes over when and why to use each. If you're a stillwater angler, or want to become one, you absolutely don't want to miss this #troutfishing #stillwater #lakefishing

00:00 Introduction
00:37 Howard's three most used stillwater methods
01:28 Starting the day
02:32 Howard's pulling setup
03:04 Starting to fish: pulling lures
04:51 Fishing the hang
07:37 Playing a fish
11:07 If it's not happening: Make it happen.
14:12 Switching methods: fishing nymphs with a midge tip
15:55 Howard's stillwater nymph setup
17:03 Starting to nymph fish
20:24 Indicator marks on your fly line
21:14 A competition strategy
23:39 Changing flies: fishing a light washing line
24:13 Greasing your fly line
29:26 How to play fish
31:20 Changing methods: dry fly fishing
32:55 Dry fly patterns
33:48 Starting off on dries
34:54 Dealing with drag
37:53 Grease versus degrease on the line and leader
40:48 How fish track in the water
44:40 A change in conditions

Howard Croston is a World Fly Fishing Champion (2019) and member of the English International Fly Fishing team. He’s also the Global Brand and Product Manager at Hardy. As one of our Signature Tyers Howard is constantly innovating new flies, and has many proven trout fly patterns in our collection. In this video you'll hear him discuss several of his flies that we carry, which are must-haves as the small stillwater season heats up
fields.author: Howard Croston
fields.snippet: walks us through his most used methods for small stillwater fly fishing

fields.name: Early Season Stillwater Tactics
fields.notes:
As with any portion of the trout season, it’s important to understand how lakes work so you can make educated assumptions as to where trout might be and why. Knowing this helps you put yourself in the right place and use the correct tactics and flies for the available food sources.

Join fellow stillwater addict, good friend, fisheries biologist, author, fly designer, business partner (Stillwater Fly Fishing Store) and TV Host with Sports Fishing on the Fly, Brian Chan and me as we discuss early season stillwater tactics.
fields.author: Phil Rowley & Brian Chan
fields.snippet: it’s important to understand how lakes work so you can make educated assumptions

fields.name: HOW TO FLY FISH USING SHRIMP/SCUDS MASTER CLASS
fields.notes: Brian Chan and Don Freschi discuss lifecycles, hatches, techniques, tips and tricks during this NEW Series of Videos for ALL Fly Anglers. The second in the Video Series is all about 'Shrimp/Scuds'. Please comment if you would like to see more of these Master Class Videos.
fields.author: Brian Chan & Don Freschi
fields.snippet: discuss lifecycles, hatches, techniques, tips and tricks

fields.name: How to Pick the Right Fly For Any Fishing Situation | Ep. 29
fields.notes: In this episode, Spencer Durrant sits down with Alex Stulce to give listeners a framework for how to pick the right fly for any fishing situation, even if you don't know anything about bugs. Dry flies, Nymphs, Streamers, Wet Flies... this information applies to every single kind of fly fishing fly. Whether you're a beginner to fly fishing, or if you've been around the block a few times, this episode is sure to have some valuable info to help you put more fish in the net.
fields.author: Ventures Fly Co.
fields.snippet: how to pick the right fly for any fishing situation,

fields.name: Beginner's Guide to Fly Fishing: 6 Insider Tips for Success | Ep. 32
fields.author: Ventures Fly Co.

fields.name: How to Successfully Fly Fish With Emergers | Ep. 46
fields.notes:
Untangled: Fly Fishing for Everyone is a question & answer based podcast where we answer questions submitted by listeners each week. In this episode, host Spencer Durrant teaches you everything you need to know about fly fishing with emergers. We'll also talk about:

- Fly rods and fly lines for saltwater fly fishing
- How to keep your flies from falling apart
- How to find big fish in small rivers
- How to pick the right dropper (aka nymph)
fields.author: Ventures Fly Co.
fields.snippet: Spencer Durrant teaches you everything you need to know about fly fishing with emergers

fields.name: How to Fly Fish With Nymphs: Our Secrets for Success | Ep. 47
fields.notes:
Untangled: Fly Fishing for Everyone is a question & answer based podcast where we answer questions submitted by listeners each week. In this episode, host Spencer Durrant is joined by Alex Stulce to talk about everything related to nymphing! You'll learn:

- How to utilize various rigs (standard nymph rigs, euro rigs, the bounce rig, etc.)
- Why nymphing is so effective
- How to get your flies into the strike zone (aka the right depth)
- How to tell if your nymphs are deep enough or too shallow
- How to pick the right fly fishing fly
- And much more!
fields.author: Ventures Fly Co.
fields.snippet: talk about everything related to nymphing!

fields.name: How to Set Up a Nymph Rig — Fly Fishing for Beginners | Module 4, Section 4
fields.notes: Nymphing is arguably the most productive way to fly fish. The majority of a trout's diet consists of bugs and other critters living below the water's surface. Using fly fishing flies that imitate these insects (and making sure you get those flies into the strike zone) is a good way to put lots of fish in the net. Today, we are going to walk you through how to set up the standard nymph rig step-by-step. You will need a leader, tippet, nymphs, split shot, and a strike indicator. Let's do this!
fields.author: Ventures Fly Co.
fields.snippet: Nymphing is arguably the most productive way to fly fish.

fields.name: Stillwater Fly Fishing: Checking Things Out - BCFLYGUYS Day Tripping S01E04
fields.notes: In this episode of Day Tripping with the flyguys we're checking out a "could be some big fish" report with an intel mission to determine if a little local lake might have some trophy trout potential! This is a neat little lake for some fall stillwater fly fishing so armed with our proven fall fly patterns we set out to see what we could do! Check it out to see how we breakdown our search, what we find, and an in show tying session for the hot fly of the day!
fields.author: BC Fly Guys

fields.name: How To Master Stillwater Retrieves for Fly Fishing - RIO Products
fields.notes:
This episode of RIO's "How To" series, is bought to you by RIO ambassador Phil Rowley. In this film Phil talks about the various retrieves that work well when fly fishing in a lake – breaking down the retrieves by length, speed, cadence and the pause between each pull. Phil talks about how to differ the retrieves according to fly style being fished – whether a bait fish pattern or a natural swimming insect.

If you enjoy fly fishing in lakes for trout but don’t have a high success rate, varying your retrieves will drastically change your success, and ensure you catch a lot more fish
fields.author: Phil Rowley
fields.snippet: varying your retrieves will drastically change your success, and ensure you catch a lot more fish

fields.name: Stillwater Fly Fishing made Simple for all year round Success. Simple, Fast, Effective.
fields.notes:
Methods and patterns we use during warmer months but have found effective during the colder months. Got to be the most enjoyable way to fish the fly with results. And even better, it's simple. Hope you enjoy the video. If you have not subscribed, then why not just click the subscribe button and hit the bell for all our content. Thanks. Shaun.

Look for the fly at 3:06
fields.snippet: Not bad show about stillwater fishing.

fields.name: Top 5 Flies and Tactics to start the 2024 Fishing Season (Stillwater Edition)
fields.notes:
This video is aimed at both experienced anglers as well as those just starting their fly fishing journey. Visiting large Stillwater can be very daunting in itself, then wondering what flies and tactics to use on such a huge expanse of water. This video will hope take some of that anxiety away. These five patterns have been proven winners over a number of years for early season Trout fishing. 

The tactics are hopefully explained clearly for fly anglers of all abilities. Again these tactics have been proven over a number of years and have served me well. If you want to catch more trout give them a go. I am positive you won't be dissapointed. 
Orange blob - 1:35 - use it as the point on a washing line.  
Comerant - 4:52 - use with the blob on a washing line.
Buzzer/Chironomid - 6:25 - 
Bobby - 
Crunchers - 11:51 - later in the spring
fields.snippet: These five patterns have been proven winners over a number of years for early season Trout fishing.
